Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: I was just about to haul another stack of lumber over to the carpenter when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old classmate I’d run into a few weeks ago. “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this afternoon? I’m really in a bind,” he texted. As an acquaintance, I felt that familiar tug—people expect you to step up when they ask for help, especially with something as stressful as moving. But at the same time, I could see the carpenter glancing over, waiting for the next load. On site, I’m expected to keep things moving, to be reliable and efficient. If I left, even for a short while, I’d be letting the crew down, slowing the whole project. My mind raced, torn between the urge to be a good friend and the responsibility to my team. I could already feel the weight of both expectations pressing down, each demanding my time and loyalty, and I stood there, phone in hand, heart pounding, not sure which way to turn.
